Award.AwardTitle: Materials World Network: Detached Bridgman Growth of Semiconductor Crystals
Award.AbstractNarration:
This effort is based on collaboration between research groups at the University of Minnesota (UMN) and the Albert-Ludwigs-Universitaet (ALU) in Freiburg, Germany. The research focuses on a novel crystal growth technique, the Detached Bridgman process, that originated in early microgravity experiments conducted during the first Skylab missions (1974). By eliminating deleterious interactions between the growing crystal and the ampoule wall, this method is capable of producing crystals with unprecedented levels of structural perfection; however, detached solidification has not yet been reliably implemented on earth. The combined experimental work at ALU and theoretical research at UMN will aim to make this process viable under terrestrial growth conditions. An important part of this joint project focuses on student exchanges that will train graduate students in both crystal growth theory and practice and will provide them with international experiences that will encourage them to become leaders in the global materials research community of tomorrow.


This activity teams two of the foremost crystal growth groups in the world to leverage their strongly complementary skills toward the realization and transformative potential of detached solidification. Experiments and theory will be conducted with complementary goals; the effort at UMN brings crystal growth modeling tools and expertise with significant computational resources available from the Minnesota Supercomputing Institute, and the ALU experimental effort leverages their mastery and state-of-the-art infrastructure for crystal growth, along with 10 years of experience with detached growth on earth and in space. Enabling the detached Bridgman process promises a means to produce large, single crystals of compound semiconductors with quality heretofore unattainable. Initial efforts will focus on growing the II-VI semiconductor cadmium zinc telluride, a material needed for high-sensitivity radiation detectors that are of great strategic importance for nuclear nonproliferation applications and securing national borders.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Due to a change in research plans of our German partner on this Materials World Network project, we changed of scope for this research project. Rather than applying computational models to understand the detached Bridgman growth of cadmium zinc telluride, our original objective, we formulated, developed, and applied similar computational models to understand the growth of cadmium zinc telluride (CZT) crystals via the traveling heater method (THM).

We successfully developed and implemented a comprehensive mathematical model for the traveling heater method (THM) that was formulated to realistically represent the interactions of heat and species transport, fluid flow, and interfacial dissolution and growth under conditions of local thermodynamic equilibrium and steady-state growth. We examined the complicated interactions among zone geometry, continuum transport, phase change, and fluid flow driven by buoyancy. Of particular interest and importance was the prediction of flow structures in the liquid zone of the THM that arose from the same physical mechanism as lee waves in atmospheric flows and demonstrated the same characteristic Brunt–Vaisaila scaling.

We showed how flow stagnation and reversal associated with lee-wave formation was responsible for the accumulation of tellurium and supercooled liquid near the growth interface, even when the lee-wave vortex was not readily apparent in the overall flow structure. The supercooled fluid was posited to result in morphological instability at growth rates far below the limit predicted by classical criteria for constitutional supercooling. Paradoxically, the traditional strategy to alleviate constitutional supercooling during crystal growth, namely increasing the temperature gradient at the interface, is expected to strengthen the lee-wave vortex and accentuate the onset of this instability. Other approaches, such as application of the accelerated crucible rotation technique (ACRT) are being evaluated to overcome growth limits in the traveling heater method.

The insights provided by this research are likely to improve the growth rates, thus reducing costs, for crystalline CZT, an important component for gamma radiation detectors. This is of immediate importance for national security, where new sensor technology is needed for securing borders. Such advances in radiation detector technology will also be important for nuclear non-proliferation applications, nuclear and particle physics experiments, medical imaging systems, astronomy, diffraction, nondestructive studies, and bore hole logging. Broader activities include the education of a graduate student in a multi-disciplinary and industrially relevant project. Finally, our research activities were directly relevant to an important national goal to maintain and improve critical competency in the area of crystal growth, as stated in a 2009 report by the National Research Council.
